overview_of_class: This course focuses on the ways in which hierarchies within the diaspora?national, gendered, economic, political and sexual?both inform and encounter resistance in literary, cultural, and scholarly discourses. In short, we will be looking at the politics of diaspora and how they inform concepts of resistance, agency, and authenticity

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
One final paper, 15pp., or one annotated bibliography, 17-20pp. Topics/theses must be approved by instructor first
Participation: 30%, Final project: 50%, presentation: 20%. Attendance: students are allowed one unexcused absence. Every subsequent unexcused absence will result in 5 points being deducted from final grade.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Readings will consist of journal articles, anthology essays, book chapters, and 1-2 full monographs. Reading may include but will not be restricted to the works of Paul Gilroy, Hortense Spillers, Daphne A Brooks, Stuart Hall, Wahneema Lubiano, Tina M. Campt, Damani Partridge,
